Some quotes:  **American voters are less ideologically polarized than they think they are, and that misperception is greatest for the most politically engaged people**.   However, most partisans hold major misbeliefs about the other partyâ€™s preferences that lead them to think there is far less shared policy belief. This perception gap is highest among progressive activists, followed closely by extreme conservatives: in other words, the people who are most involved in civic and political life hold the least accurate views of the other sideâ€™s beliefs. Figure 1 shows the gap between what groups of Americans think the other side believes and what they self-report believing, as of 2019.  **American politicians are highly ideologically polarized. In other words, they believe in and vote for different sets of policies, with little overlap. This trend has grown in a steady, unpunctuated manner for decades.**Â   One reason that the most highly politically engaged Americans may misunderstand the other side is that they correctly estimate the extreme ideological polarization among politicians.   While at this point, candidates and parties may be responding to polarized primary voters, candidates and parties have been driving the polarization, and not all voters are ideologically polarized.   The disparity between where leaders are ideologically and where their voters are precludes legislative policy agreement on many issues. Average voters are not able to assert their (often weak) policy preferences because they do not have an effective way to vote out representatives who do not accurately represent their constituentsâ€™ views, particularly on the right where party chairs are likely to substitute one extreme candidate for another.  **Even though Americans are not as ideologically polarized as they believe themselves to be, they**Â ***are***Â **emotionally polarized (known as â€œaffective polarizationâ€). In other words, they do not like members of the other party.**   Americans harbor strong dislike for members of the other party (though they also dislike their own parties, as well).Â While social media is often blamed for this phenomenon, affective polarization started growing before the internet: its onset more closely correlates with the rise of cable news and radio talk shows.  **Similarly, affective polarization is not causing political violence directly. It is probably contributing to an environment that allows politicians and opinion leaders to increase violence targeted at politicians, election officials, women, and many types of minorities.**Â   Affective polarization in the United States has been rising for decades, while political violence only increased sharply in 2016.Â Affective polarization is also quite symmetrical across parties, while political violence is overwhelmingly from the right.Â This suggests that emotional feelings of hatred toward members of the other party are not a primary cause of political violence.Â

I'd be interested to see what statistics you have to support this, but for the average American, most people are willing to listen to and control people who they don't agree with politically. The second point is definitely true, however the US doesn't spend anywhere near as much as you claim on national defese, actually about 13% in FY 23, for a total of $820 bn for all defense activities. $776 bn was spent on military activities (DoD), and $43 bn was spent on other agencies.   The majority of the DoD budget went to operations and maintenance for a total of $318 bn (40.4% of the budget), and $184 bn went to personnel (pay, healthcare for servicemembers and dependents, retirement and disability pay) and associated expenses (23.77% of the budget). The biggest thing with this is ignorance, apathy, messaging, and obscurity of these programs/policies/ laws. When was the last time you read the full Patriot Act legislation and understood every aspect of it, or read through all of the legislation that it affects?  The fourth point is true, and most politicians do have some blurb or policy positions that they believe will address poverty in the US, the problem is realizing these policies, and having them be effective.  >The don't believe politicians should only give tax breaks to the wealthy, engage in do nothing incrementalitst policies and break all of their promises. Keep in mind most Americans don't understand how our electoral systems work, and don't understand the whole process of legislation and how it becomes law. Most people don't actually try to hold elected officials accountable, most Americans only care about politics every 2,4, or 6 years. When was the last time you went to a townhall/ city council meeting where you live? When was the last time you went to a a Republicans or Democrats of Somewhereville meeting?   As a whole, most Americans aren't active politically, most American don't have the money, time, or energy to be politically active/literate/informed.
